name: Merry Christmas from Around the World! Quiz | World | 15 Questions

questions.text: Gesëende Kersfees en 'n gelukkige nuwe jaar
questions.explanation:
Afrikaans.

	Christmas in South Africa is during their summer holidays, not unlike Australia, with glorious sunny days spent at the beach or the river or sometimes camping in the mountains!

questions.text: Which of these languages is this greeting in? Pozdrevlyayu s prazdnikom Rozhdestva i Novim Godom
questions.explanation:
Russian.

	A traditional Russian Christmas involves very special prayers and the people fast!

questions.text: Nollaig chridheil agus Bliadhna mhath ur
questions.explanation:
Scots Gaelic.

	The Scots have their big celebration on New Years Day, 'Hogmanay', as such, Christmas in Scotland is a rather reserved celebration!

questions.text: Selamat Hari Natal Selamat Tahum Baru
Nadolig Llawen a Blwyddyn Newydd Dda
questions.explanation:
Welsh.

	Taffy making is a big part of a Welsh Christmas.  The special chewy toffee is made from brown sugar and butter which is boiled and then 'pulled' to make a very glossy 'taffy'!

Danish.

	A mischievous elf named 'Nisse' enjoys playing jokes on the Danes at Christmas and families leave him a bowl of rice pudding on Christmas Eve to keep in his good books!

questions.text: Joyeux Noel et une nouvelle année heureuse
questions.explanation:
French.

	In France they used to celebrate the Twelve Days of Christmas with one long holiday - Twelfth Day, as they called it, fell on 5 January!

questions.text: Tchestita Koleda i Shtastliva Nova Godina
questions.explanation:
Bulgarian.

	Christmas Eve is as important as Christmas Day in Bulgaria with a special dinner of at least twelve dishes which represent each month of the year.

questions.text: Feliz Navidad y un Feliz Año Nuevo
questions.explanation:
Spanish.

	Most homes have a manger just like in a church and it is complete with all the figurines.  Prior to Christmas, the family usually gathers around their manger to sing together.

questions.text: Fröhliche Weihnachten und ein glückliches neues Jahr
questions.explanation:
German.

	The Christmas Tree as we know it originated in Germany.  Trimming and lighting the tree was symbolistic of the tree of Paradise from the Garden of Eden!

Japanese.

	Only a small percentage of Japanese people actually believe in Christ, but most Japanese people decorate their homes at Christmas.  New Years Day is more the focus, they send 'nengajo' which are New Years cards instead of Christmas cards!

questions.text: Vrolijk Kerstfeest en een gelukkig nieuwjaar
questions.explanation:
Dutch.

	In the Netherlands, St Nicholas, who travels from Spain by boat to Holland, leaves traditional sweets and gifts for the good children on Sinterklaas Eve (5 December) whilst his 'offsider', Black Peter, beats the bad children!

questions.text: Craciun fericit si un An Nou fericit
questions.explanation:
Romanian.

	Carols form an important part of a Romanian Christmas but they are not just simple songs, they are meant as true prayers to God to hopefully give people the ability to survive everyday life!

questions.text: Mele Kalikimaka ame Hauoli Makahiki Hou
